FeedItems.Title: Getting Started With NuGet 5.8
FeedItems.Summary:
Getting started with NuGet 5.8
NuGet 5.8 is included in Visual Studio 16.8 and .NET 5.0 out of the box. You can also download NuGet 5.8 for Windows, macOS, and Linux as a standalone executable.
NuGet...

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Can't delete user certificate" (#8302) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Describe the bug
Individual account management page have trouble when trying to delete added certificates: clicking the delete button does nothing.

### To Reproduce
Add a certificate to an individual account. Try to delete it. See that nothing happens when you click the "delete" button (actually an ajax request is sent that fails).

### Expected behavior
Delete button should delete certificate.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Parallel restore randomly fails package certificate trust (in container)" (#10322) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used: NuGet.exe

NuGet version: 5.8.0.6930 (via Pipelines `NuGetToolInstaller@0` task)

VS version: 2019 Build Tools v16.8.2

OS version: Server 2019 (1809 build 17763.1577) + Docker hosting mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/framework/runtime:3.5-windowsservercore-ltsc2019

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: New scenario for us

## Description

1. Prepare a Pipelines Docker-based build agent using steps similar to those at https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/agents/docker?view=azure-devops#windows and using the `--once` agent option.

2. Use the resulting image with Docker Swarm on a 32-core host (so there are a couple of dozen agents running simultaneously).

3. Start multiple builds for solutions containing 100+ projects each with restore steps, using a nuget.config containing `<add key='maxHttpRequestsPerSource' value='4' />`.

What we are seeing is failures validating packages from nuget.org (`PackageSignatureValidity: False`). The failures appear nondeterministic -- the specific packages that succeed or fail look to be different each time, and the number of packages failing during a given run is not consistent either -- but the failure becomes more probable if more than one container's agent is restoring simultaneously.

Adding the `-DisableParallelProcessing` flag seems to make the problem go away, at the cost of a longer time to restore, while lowering `maxHttpRequestsPerSource` seems to have no effect.

Speculation: each container sees itself has having 32 CPUs, so NuGet starts 32 concurrent restore jobs (if parallel processing is left on). The error messages suggest some sort of failure during certificate validation; assuming the certificate doesn't change but the outcome does, perhaps a request rate limit is being hit somewhere?

### Verbose Logs
(Excerpts)

> NU3028: Package 'Microsoft.AspNet.Razor 3.2.3' from source 'https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json': The repository primary signature's timestamp found a chain building issue: UntrustedRoot: A certificate chain processed, but terminated in a root certificate which is not trusted by the trust provider.
> NU3018: Package 'Microsoft.AspNet.Razor 3.2.3' from source 'https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json': The repository primary signature found a chain building issue: UntrustedRoot: A certificate chain processed, but terminated in a root certificate which is not trusted by the trust provider.
> Errors in C:\vsts\_work\1\s\Web\<project_name>.csproj
>     NU3028: Package 'Microsoft.AspNet.Razor 3.2.3' from source 'https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json': The repository primary signature's timestamp found a chain building issue: UntrustedRoot: A certificate chain processed, but terminated in a root certificate which is not trusted by the trust provider.
>     NU3018: Package 'Microsoft.AspNet.Razor 3.2.3' from source 'https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json': The repository primary signature found a chain building issue: UntrustedRoot: A certificate chain processed, but terminated in a root certificate which is not trusted by the trust provider.

Later:

> PackageSignatureVerificationLog: PackageIdentity: Microsoft.AspNet.Razor.3.2.3 Source: https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json PackageSignatureValidity: False
> Package 'Microsoft.AspNet.Razor 3.2.3' from source 'https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json': Signature Hash Algorithm: SHA256
> Package 'Microsoft.AspNet.Razor 3.2.3' from source 'https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json': Timestamp: 12/14/2018 5:55:55 AM
> 
> Package 'Microsoft.AspNet.Razor 3.2.3' from source 'https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json': Verifying repository primary signature's timestamp with timestamping service certificate: 
>   Subject Name: CN=Symantec SHA256 TimeStamping Signer - G2, OU=Symantec Trust Network, O=Symantec Corporation, C=US
>   SHA1 hash: 625AEC3AE4EDA1D169C4EE909E85B3BBC61076D3
>   SHA256 hash: CF7AC17AD047ECD5FDC36822031B12D4EF078B6F2B4C5E6BA41F8FF2CF4BAD67
>   Issued by: CN=Symantec SHA256 TimeStamping CA, OU=Symantec Trust Network, O=Symantec Corporation, C=US
>   Valid from: 1/2/2017 8:00:00 AM to 4/2/2028 7:59:59 AM
> 
> Package 'Microsoft.AspNet.Razor 3.2.3' from source 'https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json':       Subject Name: CN=Symantec SHA256 TimeStamping CA, OU=Symantec Trust Network, O=Symantec Corporation, C=US

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Could not establish trust relationship for the SSL/TLS secure channel" (#10321) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
I am unable to install Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.SqlServer -Version 5.0.0 package. The following error is displayed on the console:
_PM> Install-Package Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.SqlServer -Version 5.0.0
Restoring packages for C:\Users\osunday\source\repos\ContosoUniversity\ContosoUniversity\ContosoUniversity.csproj...
Install-Package : Unable to load the service index for source https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json.
  An error occurred while sending the request.
  The underlying connection was closed: Could not establish trust relationship for the SSL/TLS secure channel.
  The remote certificate is invalid according to the validation procedure.
At line:1 char:1
+ Install-Package Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.SqlServer -Version 5.0. ...
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : NotSpecified: (:) [Install-Package], Exception
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : NuGetCmdletUnhandledException,NuGet.PackageManagement.PowerShellCmdlets.InstallPackageCommand
 
Time Elapsed: 00:00:09.3305969

However, I manage to install version 2.2.0 but was not able to scaffold because the system threw "There was an error running the selected code generator: Unable to load the service index for source https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json"
 
NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe): Package Manager Console

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): 5.8.0

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate):

VS version (if appropriate): 2019 v16.8.2

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)): win10 v1609

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: Yes, 5.8.0

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Package Manager Settings Help Button (?) in VS2019 opens outdated VS2015 specific Docs" (#9490) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Visual Studio 2019 NuGet Settings dialog in `Tools ->NuGet Package Manager -> Package Manager Settings` has a Help Button (?) which opens the Docs page specific for vs2015. 

Selecting "?" in the top right....
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49205731/80553601-72aa0200-8998-11ea-8551-7ffd94f4f7b8.png)

.....opens this [Docs Page](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/ide/adding-references-using-nuget-versus-an-extension-sdk?f1url=https%3A%2F%2Fmsdn.microsoft.com%2Fquery%2Fdev16.query%3FappId%3DDev16IDEF1%26l%3DEN-US%26k%3Dk(VS.ToolsOptionsPages.NuGet_Package_Manager.General)%26rd%3Dtrue&view=vs-2015) (with &view=vs-2015 in query string).

Note: I'm also not sure this is the best docs page as it's very generic info, and also even says it is specific to VS2015. Part of this work may be figuring out if we have a better doc to show and if not, addressing that (or in a separate docs issue).

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49205731/80553701-cddbf480-8998-11ea-9730-e3cb4e6636e7.png)

NuGet product used VSUI
NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): 16.x

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "dotnet restore on a VM breaks my internet connection and fails with errors" (#10292) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
---
**Issue moved from dotnet/sdk#14290**
- Please respond to @Loreno10.

---

_From @Loreno10 on Thursday, October 22, 2020 5:47:40 PM_

I have a Windows 10 as a host and a Pop! OS 20.04 installed using Hyper-V (enhanced session enabled, if that matters).

In the VM I have installed dotnet-sdk-3.1 and https://github.com/microsoft/artifacts-credprovider (since my dotnet project uses private NuGet feeds).

I have a .NET Core project inside of the Pop! OS VM. I'm trying to restore the dependencies using `dotnet restore`. As soon as I invoke that command, my internet connection breaks (both in the VM and the host). 
The `dotnet restore` itself throws lots of errors like this one:

> The SSL connection could not be established, see inner exception. Unable to read data from the transport connection: Connection reset by peer.

Sometimes there are also timeouts.

When I do `dotnet restore --interactive` the only difference is that initially I am asked to perform DEVICE authentication in the browser by providing some code. After that the same issue happens.

The only thing that helps in that situation is to stop the `dotnet restore` process and to turn off and turn back on my wi-fi connection (in the host). Only that restores my internet connection.

I tried the same steps multiple times:

1. Run `ping 8.8.8.8` in one terminal window (on Pop! OS)
2. Run `dotnet restore` in the other terminal window (on Pop! OS)

Around 2 seconds after I do the second step, ping from the first terminal stops receiving responses.

What could be wrong? My VM uses the "Default Switch" of Hyper-V. I did not do any special network setup. It's just a fresh installation of Pop! OS 20.04.

The same project resolved completely fine on my host and on an Ubuntu VM.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "VS2019 Nuget Package Manager can not show Project Name, but relative path of .csproj file." (#10285) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity2.visualstudio.com/t/VS2019-Nuget-Package-Manager-can-not-sho/618165)._ --- IDE: **Visual Studio 2019 16.1.3** NuGet **Package Manager: 5.1.0** Platform: **C#, .Net Framework 4.8** ### What: The Nuget Package Manager can not show the name of Project, but the relative path of *.csproj file, just like in my screenshot. **Specially, only projects which using PackageReference display this relative path of file, and projects using packages.config display project's name normally.** I don't know whether it's a bug or feature. --- ### Original Comments #### Feedback Bot on 6/24/2019, 02:27 AM:

We have directed your feedback to the appropriate engineering team for further evaluation. The team will review the feedback and notify you about the next steps.

#### Feedback Bot on 8/7/2019, 06:34 PM: We want to let you know that this problem will likely be closed in 60 days. We set priority based on severity, similar reports, and the overall impact on users and scenarios. We've also learned that reports without fresh activity could indicate that the problem isn't a problem anymore. One of our goals is to give you more transparency around these decisions as resolving every problem that gets reported isn't always possible. Your feedback is essential for helping us decide what needs the most attention, so please keep upvoting and commenting if you think that we need to make this a higher priority . #### Feedback Bot on 3/31/2020, 05:41 PM:

Thank you for sharing your feedback! Our teams prioritize action on product issues with broad customer impact. See details at: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/ide/report-a-problem?view=vs-2019#faq. In case you need answers to common questions or need assisted support, be sure to use https://visualstudio.microsoft.com/vs/support/. We’ll keep you posted on any updates to this feedback.

--- ### Original Solutions (no solutions)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Provide a means of specifying that a package is incompatible with another package" (#10250) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
It would be helpful to be able to specify in the package metadata that a particular package is incompatible with another package or with a range of versions of another package. 

Here is the use-case we have:
* We have a widely-used internal package "Monolith" which has many dependencies. We want to break up this package into smaller, more granular packages with minimal impact on existing consumers.
* To achieve this, we created a number of smaller packages "MicroPackage1", "MicroPackage2", .. "MicroPackageN" containing the various types that used to live in Monolith. We also added type forwards to Monolith.dll so that other packages that reference Monolith still work when installed in an app using the latest Monolith.

Where this breaks down is if an app using an _old_ version of Monolith installs a package which takes MicroPackage1 as a dependency. The problem is that the latest Monolith depends on MicroPackage1, but there is no way for MicroPackage1 to communicate that it is not compatible with older versions of Monolith.

We've seen this need come up in other cases as well, basically whenever we need to perform some kind of migration to a new package structure.

It would be nice to be able to express these incompatibilities in the nuspec such that consumers would find out about them upon trying to install the package.

Details (probably not relevant for this feature request):

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe): GeneratePackageOnBuild target (with .nuspec file).

NuGet version (5.7.0):

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)): Windows 10

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "November dry run for custom V2 OData query deprecation" (#48) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
We announced the deprecation of custom V2 OData queries (https://github.com/NuGet/Announcements/issues/37) last year and we will begin blocking endpoints used by 3rd party clients in **February 2021**. 

We will conduct **a dry run of the OData deprecation** to ensure that there are no surprises for users, which is scheduled to ensure overlap with normal working hours across the globe. The goal is to help you identify systems that may be affected and will give you an opportunity to take action before we permanently remove support for select v2 endpoints.
 
There will be two stages in the brown-out to accommodate a variety of usage scenarios. During these times, we will be heavily monitoring social media and other communication channels to address questions and concerns. 
	· **Nov. 11, 2020** – 3 time slots in a 24 hour period, for 4 hours each
	· **Nov. 17 & 18, 2020**  – 48 hours

Please let us know about your questions or concerns on [this discussion post](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7423).
 
Refer to the table below to identify the test slot time in your time zone.
	· UTC-9 to UTC-2 – [Green test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Green+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3923&ah=4)
	· UTC-1 to UTC+6 – [Yellow test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Yellow+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3915&ah=4)
	· UTC+7 to UTC-10 – [Blue test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Blue+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3909&ah=4)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "November dry run for custom V2 OData query deprecation" (#48) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
We announced the deprecation of custom V2 OData queries (https://github.com/NuGet/Announcements/issues/37) last year and we will begin blocking endpoints used by 3rd party clients in **February 2021**. 

We will conduct **a dry run of the OData deprecation** to ensure that there are no surprises for users, which is scheduled to ensure overlap with normal working hours across the globe. The goal is to help you identify systems that may be affected and will give you an opportunity to take action before we permanently remove support for select v2 endpoints.
 
There will be two stages in the brown-out to accommodate a variety of usage scenarios. During these times, we will be heavily monitoring social media and other communication channels to address questions and concerns. 
	· **Nov. 11, 2020** – 3 time slots in a 24 hour period, for 4 hours each
	· **Nov. 17 & 18, 2020**  – 48 hours

Please let us know about your questions or concerns on [this discussion post](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7423).
 
Refer to the table below to identify the test slot time in your time zone.
	· UTC-9 to UTC-2 – [Green test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Green+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3923&ah=4)
	· UTC-1 to UTC+6 – [Yellow test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Yellow+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3915&ah=4)
	· UTC+7 to UTC-10 – [Blue test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Blue+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3909&ah=4)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "The Microsoft author signing certificate will be updated as soon as November 1st, 2020" (#47) at NuGet/Announcements
